name: Spencer Bogart
tweet:
@TheStalwart @harrycanuck @antiprosynth As in - pre UNI, SUSHI, AAVE, etc -- we could use cool DeFi tech to trade assets but it was hard to make a case for most/any of them to have fundamental value

That changed with the cash flows associated with the native tokens (UNI, AAVE SUSHI, COMP) of these service providers

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: @TheStalwart @harrycanuck @antiprosynth BTW - an under-appreciated part of the story is the role that the native tokens of these service providers actually increased the value of their services

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: @TheStalwart @harrycanuck @antiprosynth but many of the assets that trade on Uniswap also deliver financial services similar to the way that TradFi services trade on NYSE

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet:
@TheStalwart And I think it's totally reasonable to be skeptical until there are more (new) services relevant to mainstream. That's where we're going but we're only a small part of the way there

Even at nascent stage, I hate to bring assets back to TradFi. Strong pref to keep them in Defi

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet:
@TheStalwart And I think you're right that the vast majority of people should not (yet) shift their assets over to this parallel financial system

It's incumbent for our industry to utilize programmable assets + digital infra + open networks to create new services that were not prev possible

name: Spencer Bogart
Spencer Bogart
tweet:
@guyincognito41 @TheStalwart strong agree on the "give it a try" -- even in a nascent stage, it's remarkable to be able to hold/control my assets in the digital world and directly access financial services

To be fair though, Joe is probably among a very very small % of people that *has* actually tried it

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: @amorphous_soul @PigFahy @TheStalwart @m_j_rossman I'd add that, in addition to demand for leverage, that high yields are also attributable to the inherent technical risk that we assume by using relatively new platforms and protocols

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: @TheStalwart @D_Twitt3r But now we have a system for servicing a new set of assets and by building on open networks, make those services available to a broader set of people? and with new opportunities (many yet to be discovered/created) unlocked by digital infra + programmable assets

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: @TheStalwart @D_Twitt3r So the observation that DeFi *only* helps people put their assets to work, swap between assets, and access capital -- isn't that what TradFi does for a different set of assets?

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet:
@TheStalwart @D_Twitt3r Coins = assets (money, growth assets, etc)

DeFi serves these assets -- users can earn money or more assets by putting their money and assets to work. Or they can borrow against them

name: Spencer Bogart
Spencer Bogart
tweet:
@TheStalwart Ran out of time to fully address the Q

natively digital assets + apps + infra unlocks new possibilities for programmable assets

Flash Loans remove capital as a barrier to improving market efficiency

Lending/trading pools democratize access to lending and MMing

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet:
The passage of time itself is a huge tailwind for Bitcoin. Every year, the general pop, regardless of age is more inclined to owning and using BTC.

And, every year, currently younger demographics (whom are most inclined to BTC) comprise a larger share of the aggregate economy

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: @WR_Crypto @HHorsley That figure in particular definitely causes me to ü§î. Maybe people overstate their ownership? I'm really not sure but my cursory guess would be that actual ownership is a bit lowerü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet:
11/ Check out the full post, data, charts, and survey methodology here: 
https://t.co/hvffhYfZMo

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 10/ Lastly in the conviction phase ‚Äì we gauge purchase propensity by asking participants how likely they are to buy Bitcoin in the next 5 years. At time of survey, Bitcoin was still ~50% below ATH. Still, we saw a surge in the general population‚Äôs propensity to purchase BTC. https://t.co/NQ2j1yjCh2

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 9/ We also gauge the general population‚Äôs preference for Bitcoin relative to other assets by asking whether they would prefer $1k of BTC over $1k of other major assets. Preference rates for BTC were up across the board https://t.co/cGfCNYON55

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 8/ We added a new question to the 2020 survey asking whether participants expect Bitcoin or the euro to exist longer. I expected single digit % to select BTC. Instead, 38% of Americans indicated they expect Bitcoin to exist longer than the euro‚Äîincluding 58% of those aged 18-34. https://t.co/8fyhTaY70e

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 7/ There was shockingly strong growth in the percentage of people that indicated ‚Äúit‚Äôs likely that most people will be using Bitcoin in the next 10 years‚Äù‚Äîincluding 56% of those aged 18-34 (up 8 percentage points) and 57% of those aged 35-44 (up 19 percentage points) https://t.co/1CDcxog2B3

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 6/ You can check out the results from the ‚ÄúLearning Phase‚Äù in the blog link at top of this thread ‚Äì but I‚Äôll skip to the most interesting part ‚Äì the ‚ÄúConviction Phase‚Äù where we saw exceptional growth in the Fall 2020 results.

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 5/ If you‚Äôre short on time and don‚Äôt want to dig through the charts below, here‚Äôs a few highlights: https://t.co/JoHEw3GLdP

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 4/ In terms of high-level takeaways what‚Äôs most notable is that from Fall 2017 to Spring 2019 we saw the strongest growth in the ‚Äúlearning phase‚Äù of the adoption funnel. In contrast, in the most recent survey we saw the strongest growth in the ‚Äúconviction phase‚Äù of the funnel.

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 3/ The intent is to measure the progression of the general population through the crypto adoption funnel which can be broken down into three major components (‚Äúlearning phase‚Äù, ‚ÄúConviction Phase‚Äù, and ‚ÄúAdoption Phase‚Äù) https://t.co/qxYopGr3HB

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 2/ Background ‚Äì the survey was conducted by The Harris Poll on behalf of Blockchain Capital from Oct 7-9, 2020. More than 2,000 individuals participated in the survey which was an augmented version of a similar survey we ran in Spring 2019 and Fall 2017.

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet:
1/ Sharing new data highlighting how Bitcoin is (still) a demographic mega-trend.

This is our third data update and it effectively highlights how the American population is progressing through the adoption funnel.

https://t.co/hvffhYfZMo

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 10/ All this matters to us as a venture firm because it ties back to the current and prospective health of the broader industry. And as we‚Äôve seen from bellwethers like Coinbase and Kraken, the industry has seen a notable uptick across KPIs since the disruption ensued.

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 9/ All this against a Macro backdrop that saw G-7 central banks purchase more than $1.4 Trillion of assets in the back-half of March alone. The Fed alone is purchasing assets at a pace equivalent to Bitcoin‚Äôs market cap every 3-4 days.

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 8/ Taken together, the crypto industry‚Äôs rapid de-leveraging and concurrent increase in dry powder were the set-up for Bitcoin‚Äôs significant outperformance since Black Thursday ‚Äì performance which supports and reinforces Bitcoin‚Äôs position as an early-stage store of value

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 7/ And this de-leveraging coupled with an influx from cash, led to a surge in stablecoin ‚Äòdry powder‚Äô balances. Stablecoin balances aren‚Äôt just at an all-time-high ‚Äì importantly, they‚Äôre at an ATH relative to Bitcoin market cap. https://t.co/t2ZaCYfhJx

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 6/ Can‚Äôt do this without talking de-leveraging. Interesting thing here is that crypto de-leveraging was like ripping a band-aid off quickly over a 36hr period, whereas it seems to be playing out over a much longer period in other asset classes. https://t.co/MVGXxIClGG

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 5/ Shifting to (much discussed) market-related items ‚Äì Per @coinmetrics, Black Thursday selling was largely driven by recently moved UTXOas ‚Äì so while short-term speculators were shaken out of the market, long-term holders appear almost entirely unfazed https://t.co/SzBTGVxb2M

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 4/ Supply-side services (e.g. full nodes, hash rate) are provisioned remotely and digitally while network demand is driven by (increasing) demand to move and use Bitcoin as a digital, scarce, apolitical asset with 24/7 liquidity and ‚Äòalways on‚Äô financial infrastructure https://t.co/Ca2dhZJvO6

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 3/ Of course, with a closer look at the supply and demand sides of the Bitcoin network, this resiliency is no surprise

name: Spencer Bogart
tweet: 2/ Bitcoin fundamentals (e.g. tx value, hash rate) certainly took a hit around Black Thursday but relative to longer-histories these are but mere ‚Äòblips‚Äô. The Bitcoin network adjusted to the shock and didn‚Äôt miss a beat. https://t.co/lTzDjCM53n
